p.s: Is it time for hope, after COP26?
The outcome from COP26 with regards to German perspective
In November of this year 2021, the 26th conference, COP26 about climate change took place in Glasgow.
This is a yearly conference since 1994, where governments of nearly every country of the world, 196 governments take part in.
It is a conference based on climate change and how to deal with it.
The governments discuss and decide on what to do, to prevent the earth of getting warmer.
All of these countries are also part of the United Nations and therefore work together.
Germany also took part in the COP26 in Glasgow.
But how is the German perspective on the outcome of COP26?
Jochen Flasbarth, the state secretary at the Ministry for the Environment and Nature Protection has an answer to that question.
According to him, the COP26 in Glasgow cleared a path to achieve the climate goal of 1.5 degrees Celsius, which was set in the Paris agreement.
However, it has to be clear that the UNUnited Nations and the COP meetings are not governments.
They only can call for action, but cannot set a law for the countries who participate.
Therefore, the countries have to implement the decision that was made at the conference.
Furthermore, Mr. Flasbarth goes into detail about abandoning coal power.
Yes, the problem with China and India remains.
They denied the complete abandonment of coal and rather want a gradual reduction.
This is not the best thing, especially for countries like Germany who definitely would vote for a complete reduction of coal power.
The European Union (EU) brought up the topic at COP26.
The most surprising was that for the first time, it was accepted.
Because for many countries, coal power is one of the most important income and at COP26 they agreed to a phase down.
This means that the time of coal will be over soon, which is great to hear.
Moreover, climate experts predicted the global warming lower than before the Paris agreement.
Before the Paris agreement in 2015, they predicted a rise of five to six degrees.
Before the conference COP26 in 2021, it has fallen to 2.7 degrees.
According to Flasbarth this is a huge process.
I agree with Flasbarth that a step has been made in the right direction.
And yes, in a German perspective the outcome is quite good.
However, more concrete decisions must be made.
I know that it is very hard to deal with climate change and the UNUnited Nations cannot propose laws about abandoning coal power for example.
But projects like A legal framework for impact by Freshfields, where they invest in companies to stop emitting are a great option.
Because the problem is that every emission which is produced in the air, has to be reduced somewhere else: concept of balance.
In conclusion, the outcome of COP26 is a good way in the right direction.
For Germany the outcome is quite good, however the reduction of coal power should be a complete reduction by 2030 according to German politics.
